> I've started investigating JUnit and I'm finding that for methods in my
> application that have some non trivial logic (basically multiple if paths
> through the method) that my JUnit tests are becoming unwieldy to setup and
> maintain. I'm retrofitting unit tests onto an existing large J2EE app.

To me, one of the benefits of tests is that they help me to spot design
problems early. Whenever I find it difficult to write a test for a method, I
ask myself whether it's the method's fault.

Your method checks a number of fields from another class and selects its
behaviour based on the value of those fields. It looks like a case of
Feature Envy, meaning that you pull out information from someone else to
decide what to do. Shouldn't this decision be delegated to the owner of the
information itself (Move Method refactoring)? Also, those conditionals look
like an ideal target for the Replace Conditional with Polymorphism
refactoring. Maybe the "status" object could be the thing to delegate these
decisions to, after turning it into its own hierarchy? These are just hints,
and they might not work. Your approach could be justified by the desire to
take DB-related methods out of the Customer business class. Still, I would
investigate in other ways to do the same thing with less conditionals.

Sometimes I see a test as a particularly exacting and low-level "user" of
the system. As for real users, tests sometimes complain that the system is
too complex. We should never assume that the user is stupid. Maybe the
system really *is* too complex.
